title: Dylan Edwards injury update: Kansas State RB out vs Iowa State with ankle issue
description: Dylan Edwards is out for the remainder of Kansas State's Week 0 game against Iowa State on Saturday, Aug. 23, with an apparent ankle injury.
content:
Kansas State football running back Dylan Edwards will miss the rest of the Wildcats' game against Iowa State on Saturday, Aug. 23 with an apparent ankle injury.

Edwards, K-State's starting running back, left the Aer Lingus College Football Classic in Dublin, Ireland, early in the first quarter after appearing to injure his ankle after receiving a punt. Wildcats coach Chris Klieman told the ESPN broadcast at halftime that Edwards will miss the remainder of the game.

Losing the second-year transfer from Colorado is a big blow for K-State, as the 5-foot-9 speedster had 546 rushing yards with five touchdowns last season behind now-Indianapolis Colts running back DJ Giddens. He also provides quarterback Avery Johnson with a strong option in the passing game.

Edwards had a standout freshman season at Colorado, scoring four touchdowns in the Buffaloes' 2023 season opener against TCU.

Here's what to know of Edwards' injury against the Cyclones on Aug. 23.

Edwards only played one snap and didn't see the field on offense before exiting the game against Iowa State, as he muffed a punt that led to an apparent ankle injury. His ankle was taped on the sideline before he exited the field to the locker room.

Edwards later returned to the sideline, although it was without his helmet and with a towel over his head. He didn't appear the rest of the first half before Klieman confirmed he will miss the remainder of the game.

It's unclear the severity of Edwards' injury, although it's certainly a big blow to Kansas State's offense in the top-25 Big 12 matchup.

keywords.name: Kansas State football running back Dylan Edwards

summary: Kansas State football running back Dylan Edwards will miss the remainder of the team's game against Iowa State due to an ankle injury. Edwards, who was a second-year transfer from Colorado, left the Aer Lingus College Football Classic in Dublin, Ireland early in the first quarter due to the injury. The loss of Edwards is a significant blow for K-State, as he had 546 rushing yards with five touchdowns last season and provides a strong passing option for quarterback Avery Johnson. The injury is unclear how severe it will be, but it is believed that Edwards will be replaced by the University of Kansas.
shortSummary: Kansas State's Dylan Edwards is out of the game against Iowa State due to an ankle injury, leaving a significant gap between him and his team.

scraped_sources.text:
Dylan Edwards injury update: Kansas State football RB ruled out for rest of Iowa State game
Kansas State football coach Chris Klieman told ESPN at halftime that starting running back Dylan Edwards is out for the remainder of the team's Week 0 opener against Iowa State in Ireland.
Edwards played one snap. He muffed a punt after Iowa State's first drive, leading to his left ankle being taped on the sideline before he went to the locker room. Edwards was seen on the sideline with a Gatorade towel over his head and without his helmet.
Edwards didn't take a snap with the offense, leading to Joe Jackson getting the start in the backfield. He ran the ball 10 times for 40 yards and gave up a fumble during the first half.
Kansas State and Iowa State were tied at seven at the end of the first half.
Dylan Edwards injury update
Klieman said Edwards has been ruled out for the remainder of the game.
Edwards left the game after muffing a punt after Kansas State got a stop on the Cyclones' first drive. ESPN reported his ankle was being taped, and showed him walking back to the locker room under his own power early in the first quarter.
Dylan Edwards injury video: RB exits after muffed punt
Joe Jackson: Kansas State running back replaced Dylan Edwards
Jackson was expected to have a major role in the Wildcats' backfield. He had four carries for eight yards through K-State's first two drives.

Kansas State University Athletics
2024 Football Roster
Edwards, Dylan
Jersey Number 3
Dylan Edwards
- Position:
- Running Back
- Height:
- 5-9
- Weight:
- 167
- Class:
- Sophomore
- Hometown:
- Derby, Kan.
- High School:
- Derby
- Prev School:
- Univ. of Colorado
Bio
CAREER HONORS
• 2025 Maxwell Award watch list
• 2025 Doak Walker Award watch list
• 2025 Paul Hornung Award watch list
• 2025 Jet Award watch list
• 2024 Rate Bowl Offensive MVP
• 2024 All-Big 12 Honorable Mention [kr/pr] (Coaches)
• 2024 Honorable Mention Big 12 Offensive Newcomer of the Year (Coaches)
• 2024 Big 12 Special Teams Player of the Week (Arizona)
• 2024 All-Bowl Team (Associated Press)
• 2024 Paul Hornung Award watch list
• 2024 Academic All-District (College Sports Communicators)
• 2023 Pac-12 Freshman of the Week (TCU)
2024: Played in 12 games with six starts, rushing for 546 yards and five touchdowns on 74 carries in addition to totaling 133 receiving yards and two touchdowns on 19 catches as he earned votes for the Big 12 Offensive Newcomer of the Year award from the league’s coaches… His 7.4-yard rushing average ranked first among Power 4 running backs (minimum 70 carries), while he teamed with DJ Giddens (6.6-yard average) and Avery Johnson (5.4-yard average) to make K-State the only Power 4 team in the country with three players averaging at least 5.4 yards per rush (minimum 70 carries)… Rushed for a career high 196 yards – including a career-long rush of 65 yards – and two touchdowns while he hauled in two passes for 27 yards and another score in the Rate Bowl against Rutgers as he was named the game’s Offensive MVP and earned a spot on the Associated Press All-Bowl Team… His 196 rushing yards – which were highlighted by a 65-yard touchdown run to begin a 17-point comeback – were the third most in school history by a sophomore and the most ever by a Wildcat in a bowl game… His 223 all-purpose yards also ranked second in K-State bowl history, while his total points tied for second and rushing touchdowns tied for sixth… It was the second most rushing yards and yards from scrimmage in a bowl game during the 2024 season… His effort in the bowl topped his previous career high of 60 rushing yards against Kansas, which included a long of 44 yards… Also passed the 50-yard rushing mark at Tulane with 54 yards and a touchdown on just four carries… Added rushing touchdowns in the season opener against UT Martin and at Colorado, while he also had a receiving touchdown in the season opener… Served as one of the Wildcats’ primary return men during the season, totaling 140 punt-return yards with a touchdown on 10 attempts and 298 kickoff-return yards on 15 attempts to pick up All-Big 12 Honorable Mention accolades from the league’s coaches as a returner… Finished 35th nationally in combined kick return yards (438), while he was fifth in the Big 12 in total punt return yards and eighth in kickoff return yards… Returned a punt 71 yards for a touchdown against Arizona en route to Big 12 Special Teams Player of the Week honors… It was the first punt return touchdown by a K-State running back since Darren Sproles in 2003 and longest by a K-State running back since David Allen in 1999 (74 yards)… Became the first Wildcat with at least one rushing, receiving and return touchdown in the first three games of a season since Deon Murphy in 2007… Saw time on 232 offensive snaps and 74 special teams plays during the season… Named to the watch list for the 2024 Paul Hornung Award and was an Academic All-District selection by College Sports Communicators.
2023 AT UNIV. OF COLORADO: Played in all 12 games with six starts, including starts in each of the first four games of the season... Registered 321 rushing yards and one touchdown on 76 carries, while he hauled in 36 receptions for 299 yards and four scores... The first true freshman in Colorado history with at least 250 rushing yards and 250 receiving yards in the same season, while it was only the ninth time ever in school history... Had the most receiving touchdowns by a CU true freshman since 2010, while he tied for the most receiving touchdowns by a running back... Also returned five kickoffs for 105 yards (21.0-yard average) and two punts for 19 yards... Broke out in his first-career game at TCU, catching five passes for 135 yards and three touchdowns to go along with 24 rushing yards and another score on six carries en route to Pac-12 Freshman of the Week accolades... Set the Colorado single-game record for most receiving yards and touchdowns by a running back, while he tied the school’s overall receiving touchdown record... Had the Buffaloes’ first touchdown on the year, making him the first true freshman to have the first points of the season since 2002... The first player in seven seasons to score four touchdowns from scrimmage in his FBS debut, while he was just the fourth true freshman to accomplish the feat in the past 27 seasons... Posted a season-high 57 rushing yards against Colorado State a week after totaling 55 yards against Nebraska, the latter that included a season-long rush of 34 yards... Had a 30-yard touchdown reception in the season finale at Utah… Was in for 392 offensive snaps and 56 special teams plays.
HIGH SCHOOL: A four-year letterwinner at Derby under head coach Brandon Clark, a former K-State wide receiver... Regarded as one of the nation’s top 100 prospects for the Class of 2023 by Rivals, while the organization rated him the third-best running back in the class and the top overall prospect in the state of Kansas... Rated a top-150 prospect, seventh-best running back and second-best overall player in Kansas by ESPN, while he was viewed as a top-225 prospect, the seventh-best running back and the second-best prospect in Kansas by 247Sports... A two-time Top 11 honoree by the Wichita Eagle and Sports in Kansas... Named the Sports in Kansas 6A Offensive Player of the Year as both a junior and senior... Helped Derby to a 42-7 record over his career, which included state championships as a freshman and sophomore, and a runner-up finish as a junior... Rushed for 6,426 yards and 95 touchdowns on 622 carries over his four seasons, which included 32 games with at least 100 rushing yards in his 36 total games played... Also had 40 receptions for 556 yards and seven touchdowns, 15 kickoff returns for 521 yards and three touchdowns, and 16 punt returns for 441 yards and three touchdowns... Named the Kansas Gatorade Player of the Year as a junior when he led the Panthers to an 11-1 record, rushing 208 times for 2,603 yards and 38 touchdowns... Had a least 100 rushing yards in every game as a junior, including six 200-yard games and one 300-yard output... Also played baseball.
PERSONAL: Dylan Edwards was born September 22, 2004, in Derby, Kansas... Son of Leon and Raisha Edwards... Has three siblings, Kevion, Cydney and Chatara... Father, Leon, was a running back for the Wildcats, lettering the 1992 through 1994 seasons... Majoring in communications.

The 2025 college football season is set to kick off in Ireland with what should be a thrilling, high-stakes Big 12 conference game.
The Kansas State Wildcats are playing the Iowa State Cyclones in a Week 0 college football game in the Aer Lingus Classic. Follow live updates.
Kansas State and Iowa State are in Dublin for a Week 0 Big 12 college football game. Follow live updates:
The Frisco, Texas native scored his first collegiate touchdown Saturday on a 24-yard fade route from quarterback Rocco Becht.
The ACC has a team playing in Week 0. Here's our final preseason ACC Power Rankings before that game kicks off.

Kansas State football vs. Iowa State live updates: Wildcats, Cyclones in close game late
Chris Klieman and the Kansas State Wildcats open the 2025 football season in Ireland with the Aer Lingus College Football Classic against Iowa State at Aviva Stadium. A Week 0 showdown, the game will reverberate throughout the Big 12 regardless of the result, as quarterback Avery Johnson looks to leave his mark in Manhattan.
It will be the second time in their past three games the Wildcats have faced the Cyclones, having lost to Iowa State in the final game of the regular season last year. The Cyclones are led by quarterback Rocco Becht, who is hoping to build on a strong 2024 campaign.
Stream Kansas State vs Iowa State on Fubo (free trial)
The Topeka Capital-Journal is bringing you live updates, scores and highlights from the game.
Kansas State vs Iowa State live score
This section will be updated near kickoff.
| TEAMS | 1Q | 2Q | 3Q | 4Q | F |
| Iowa State | 7 | 0 | 7 | — | — |
| Kansas State | 0 | 7 | 0 | — | — |
Fourth quarter: Iowa State 17, Kansas State 14.
Iowa State retakes lead with field goal
The Cyclones retake the lead with a 34-yard field goal from Konrady, who is now 1-of-2 on the day kicking. Iowa State answers, but Kansas State will get the ball back with a chance to take its first lead of the game.
Kansas State responds in a big way
That was Avery Johnson's best series of the game, and frankly one of the best of his K-State career.
On multiple dropbacks, Johnson completes 4 of 5 passes for 85 yards and caps it off with a touchdown to Jayce Brown just two plays after nearly connecting with Brown from 44 yards. Huge answer for the Wildcats, and it's 14-14 late.
Third quarter: Iowa State 14, Kansas State 7
Third quarter ends with big play for Kansas State
The Kansas State offense has looked at its best when answering an Iowa State score. First Johnson threads the needle with a 17-yard completion to Jayce Brown, then he climbs the pocket and finds a wide open Oakley for 24 yards down to the Iowa State 44-yard line. Now, Kansas State will try to make the most of yet another trip into ISU territory.
Iowa State retakes the lead
Becht throws his second TD pass of the game with a dime to Brett Eskilsden. Eskilden's second catch of the day goes for 24 yards and a touchdown, and Iowa State is back on top.
Iowa State moving the ball again
Following the turnover on downs, Iowa State is pushing the ball on the ground. The Cyclones are in the midst of a 10-play drive for 46 yards that has taken 5:43 off the clock. A fourth-down conversion kept the drive alive.
Kansas State offense sputters
Not a great look for offensive coordinator Matt Wells. After Johnson complete a few plays, a QB draw and reverse put Kansas State in the hole on third down. A throw at the line of scrimmage puts Kansas State in fourth-and-8, and a dropped pass leads to a turnover on downs. Chris Klieman is calling this game aggressively, but the playcalling isn't matching his pace.
Iowa State punts it away after three-and-out
Same situation for Iowa State. Nothing to be found, with a huge Kansas State sack halting the Cyclones' ensuing drive in its tracks.
Wildcats go three-and-out
So much for mometum.
Kansas State goes three-and-out despite getting itself in a favorable third-and-2 situation. An Avery Johnson pass at the line of scrimmage gets blown up, and Iowa State will start from its own 42-yard line.
Kansas State receives to start second half
Kansas State will start the second half with the ball, and returns it to the 19-yard line. The offense will try to find momentum early.
Halftime: Kansas State 7, Iowa State 7
It feels like Week 0.
Kansas State and Iowa State's offenses have both had ample scoring opportunities, but both sides have just one touchdown to their respective names. Iowa State struck first on a gorgeous throw from Rocco Becht, while Avery Johnson ran in a touchdown on a tremendous keeper read.
Dylan Edwards is out for the game for Kansas State, and Joe Jackson will get the lion's share of carries from there on out. The Wildcats have moved the ball fairly well on the ground, but the turnover bug is proving to be a serious issue as drives continue. Iowa State's ground game, meanwhile, has just 23 yards to its name thus far.
Both coaches will look to clean things up in the second half, but in a Week 0 game on a damp field, this one might come down to survival and ball security more than anything else.
Second quarter: Kansas State 7, Iowa State 7
Kansas State drive sputters out
Kansas State looked like it was starting to move the ball, but a pass interference call and airmailed throw from Johnson lead to a punt. Iowa State fields the punt at its own 4-yard line, and both teams just look ready to get to the locker room.
Cyclones miss 49-yard field goal
It's another empty turnover for Iowa State. The Cyclones miss a 49-yard field goal attempt after failing to convert on third down, ad Kansas State gets the ball back from its own 31-yard line.
Iowa State driving after turnover
Although both teams have squandered turnovers deep in opposing territory, Iowa State is threatening after the Jackson fumble. The Cyclones have converted a fourth down to keep this drive alive, and Iowa State faces third-and-9 from the Kansas State 31-yard line.
Joe Jackson fumbles away K-State possession
The Wildcats were moving the ball well with a big completion to Garrett Oakley, but Jackson fumbles it away after a big gain up the middle. That's now four fumbles lost between these two teams... In the first half.
Kansas State forces yet another Iowa State punt
No momentum shift after the turnover on downs, as the Wildcats force another Iowa State three-and-out. Wildcats will start on their own 41-yard line.
Iowa State responds by forcing turnover on downs
Kansas State got a huge stop after a muffed punt in the first quarter. Now the Cyclones do the same following the Becht fumble. Klieman rolls the dice with a dive play to Joe Jackson on fourth-and-1, and Iowa State knifes through the line to stop Jackson short and force a turnover on downs. Defense continues to be showcased in Ireland.
Kansas State defense forces another turnover
Ball security continues to be an issue in this game, and snakebites the Cyclones once again. On third-and-long, Kansas State pins its ears back and strips Rocco Becht. The Wildcats will start from the Iowa State 16-yard line looking to take their first lead.
Kansas State opens second quarter with Avery Johnson TD
It shouldn't surprise anyone to see Avery Johnson keep the ball on the ground, but the Wildcats QB keeps the ball on the read option and the entire Iowa State defense bites. Kansas State ties the game at seven, and we have a new ballgame here in Dublin.
First quarter: Iowa State 7, Kansas State 0
First quarter ends with Kansas State threatening
The first quarter ends with Kansas State trailing 7-0, but the Wildcats will start the second with a third-and-4 deep in Iowa State territory. Kansas State has been unable to throw the ball, but the ground game has the Wildcats on the move.
Iowa State gets on the board
Dominic Overby's second catch of the day is a gorgeous ball from Rocco Becht for a touchdown. Becht hits Overby on a 23-yard fade, and Iowa State takes an early lead in Ireland. Becht was 3-for-3 for 46 yards on the scoring drive.
Dylan Edwards goes to Kansas State locker room, Kansas State punts again
Another three-and-out for Kansas State, but the Wildcats now have bigger issues. Dylan Edwards' knee was injured on that muffed punt, and the Colorado transfer has gone to the Kansas State locker room.
Read more about Edwards' injury here.
Cyclones punt it away
Despite the first completion of the game from either side from Becht to Dominic Overby, Iowa State goes three-and-out and punts it away. Kansas State starts from its own 16-yard line for its second series of the game.
Wildcats go three-and-out on opening series
Weather is looking like a factor in Ireland.
Kansas State goes three-and-out in a run-run-pass series. It's hard to be overly inspiring calling plays when it's raining. On his lone pass attempt, Johnson underthrows his receiver who drops what is still a catchable ball, and Iowa State will get the ball back.
Kansas State gets the ball following ISU fumble
Oh, so it's one of THOSE games.
Iowa State returns Kansas State's favor with a botched toss, and the Wildcats fall on the ball! Huge stand for the defense, and Avery Johnson will take the field for the first time in a scoreless game.
Iowa State drive continues after pass interference
Mental errors are taking a toll early for Kansas State. VJ Payne gets called for pass interference at the top of an Iowa State corner route, and the drive continues.
Kansas State forces punt on opening drive, muffs punt
The Wildcat defense won't take kindly to that. After allowing a first down, Kansas State forces a punt. However, it muffs the punt and Iowa State gets the ball back on the Kansas State 8-yard line without the defense taking a snap. Brutal start for K-State's special teams.
Kansas State-Iowa State set to kickoff
Kansas State won the toss and deferred to the second half. Iowa State will receive first to kick off the 2025 season.
Kansas State, Iowa State nearly ready to kick off
The stage is set for Kansas State vs Iowa State, with the Wildcats and Cyclones taking the field. Week 0 and college football are just around the corner.
Kansas State vs Iowa State injury report
Neither Kansas State nor Iowa State enter this game completely healthy, with safety Gunner Maldonado being probable, Asa Newsom questionable and Colby McCalister out.
See the full injury report here.
Rocco Becht stats vs Kansas State
Rocco Becht is 2-0 in his two games against the Wildcats.
In his first game, he completed 8 of 12 passes for 230 yards and three touchdowns. Last season, Becht went 13 of 35 for two touchdowns and rushed eight times for 35 yards and another touchdown.
Avery Johnson stats vs Iowa State
In a loss to Iowa State last season, Wildcats QB Avery Johnson completed 12 of 28 passes for 220 yards and three touchdowns. It was his only game with under a 50% completion percentage on the season. Johnson also ran 13 times for 64 yards.
Kansas State-Iowa State Farmageddon nickname
Plenty of rivalry games have kitschy nicknames, but perhaps none is quirkier than Kansas State-Iowa State's "Farmageddon" moniker.
Why are Kansas State, Iowa State playing in Ireland?
Kansas State and Iowa State are facing off in Ireland for the Aer Lingus Classic.
Read the USA TODAY network to find out more about this international series, and why Aviva Stadium has become a Week 0 staple.
What is college football's Week 0?
Kansas State vs Iowa State is the headliner, but what is Week 0 in college football? Why is it played? Find out by reading.
What time does Kansas State vs Iowa State start?
- Date: Saturday, Aug. 23
- Time: 11 a.m. CT
- Where: Aviva Stadium (Dublin)
What TV channel is Kansas State vs Iowa State on today?
- TV: ESPN
- Streaming: ESPN app | ESPN+ | Fubo (free trial)
Kansas State vs. Iowa State will air on ESPN. Streaming options include the ESPN app or ESPN+, which serves as the network's subscription streaming service. Another option is Fubo, which offers a free trial to new subscribers.
Watch Kansas State football with Fubo (free trial)
Kansas State vs Iowa State predictions
- Wyatt D. Wheeler, Topeka Capital-Journal: Kansas State
- Travis Hines, Des Moines Register: Iowa State
Kansas State football schedule 2025
* - Denotes Big 12 game
- Saturday, Aug. 23: vs Iowa State (Dublin)*
- Saturday, Aug. 30: vs North Dakota
- Saturday, Sept. 6: vs Army

argos_summary: Kansas State running back Dylan Edwards suffered an ankle injury after muffing a punt in the Week 0 game against Iowa State in Dublin, leaving him out for the rest of the contest. The 5‑foot‑9 transfer had been a key contributor last season, rushing for 546 yards and five touchdowns, and his absence is a significant blow to the Wildcats’ offense. Edwards’ exit came early in the first quarter, and the game remained a tight Big 12 matchup as both teams struggled with ball security.
